p: We obtained data on daily average temperature (°C) from the Ultuna Climate Station (59°82′N, 17°65′E; http://grodden.evp.slu.se/slu_klimat/index.html) ~10 km from the center of our study area. Plant and arthropod development early in the season is strongly determined by degree days, that is, temperature exceeding a threshold (base) temperature below which growth and development rate is zero. Insect phenology models are usually based on accumulated degree‐days (i.e., the cumulative sum of degree days during a time period; Hodgson et al., 2011; Nietschke, Magarey, Borchert, Calvin, & Jones, 2007). We therefore used thermal sum as an indicator of spring phenology: with degree days = daily mean temperature − base temperature, and thermal sum for each day calculated as the cumulative sum of degree days since January 1 in each year. We used a base temperature of 5°C, which is the threshold used by the Swedish Meteorological and Hydrological Institute ( https://www.smhi.se) to analyze the start of the growing season in agricultural areas (Persson, Bärring, Kjellström, Strandberg, & Rummukainen, 2007).
